title: Teacher Competency Diagnostic Test (TCDT)
description: Comprehensive assessment across 6 PD tracks covering 250 questions

scoring.0: Insensitive or dismissive tone / No instructional terms / Completely illogical
scoring.1: Limited empathy or forced tone / Vague strategy / Weak logic
scoring.2: Generally warm and student-focused / Some relevant language / Mostly logical
scoring.3: Empathetic, calm, and appropriate / Effective vocabulary / Well-structured

scoring.0: Insensitive or dismissive tone / No instructional terms / Completely illogical
scoring.1: Limited empathy or forced tone / Vague strategy / Weak logic
scoring.2: Generally warm and student-focused / Some relevant language / Mostly logical
scoring.3: Empathetic, calm, and appropriate / Effective vocabulary / Well-structured

questions.prompt: You've designed a science project that's exciting, but students are missing key concepts. What should you do?
options: Reduce project scope and reteach basics

questions.prompt: A student keeps interrupting during your explanation. What's the best first step?
You're using an AI chatbot for student feedback. What's the biggest risk?
What's a responsible way to use generative AI in class?
options: Use it to replace your slides
Explain how it works to students
Let students play with it unmonitored

questions.prompt: A student avoids group work due to social anxiety. Your best response?
You notice your lesson materials lack cultural diversity. What should you do?
options: Use only diverse examples going forward

questions.prompt: You made an error in grading. A student points it out. You should...
You're struggling to meet your school's PD hours. What should you do?
options: Log a plan and attend PDs later

questions.prompt: How would you integrate SDGs into a primary lesson?
options: Add group work with token roles

questions.prompt: Which of the following reflects Piaget's theory of cognitive development?
options: Learning is continuous and based on experience
Learning occurs in stages with active exploration
Development is unrelated to teaching methods

questions.prompt: Describe a time when your lesson failed. What did you learn?
How do you decide whether or not to use an AI tool in a lesson?
Explain how you modify your lessons for students with learning disabilities.
What does professional growth mean to you as a teacher?
How do you approach teaching controversial global topics?
What role does child psychology play in your daily teaching practice?
How do you make students from diverse cultures feel included in your class?
Describe a responsible use case of AI that improved your teaching.
Tell us about a moment when you mentored a colleague or peer.
What strategies do you use to reflect on and improve your lessons?

You're explaining your teaching approach to a skeptical parent. Speak as you would in a real conversation.
A student feels left out of group activities. Respond with empathy and solutions.
A colleague is violating school policies. Confront them diplomatically.
You're advocating for AI tools to your school head. Make your case clearly.
Explain how you integrate SDGs in your curriculum to a fellow teacher.
Coach a struggling new teacher about effective classroom routines.
Handle a conflict between students from different cultural backgrounds.
Demonstrate how you introduce an AI writing assistant to a class.
Speak to a parent about a student's social-emotional challenges.
Describe the importance of learning theories in shaping your lesson plans.

I feel confident using AI tools to support student learning.
I adjust my teaching based on ongoing student feedback.
I know how to support neurodiverse learners effectively.
I consistently reflect on my teaching to improve it.
I integrate global issues like sustainability in my lessons.
I understand how children develop across different age groups.
I design inclusive learning environments for all students.
I understand the ethical risks of using AI in class.
I welcome constructive feedback from my colleagues.
I use questioning techniques to promote deep thinking.

You catch a student cheating. What do you do?
questions.bestResponse: Privately address it, apply school policy, and offer a learning opportunity

questions.prompt: You're forced to teach a lesson outside your subject expertise. How do you respond?
questions.bestResponse: Consult peers, gather resources, prepare responsibly

questions.prompt: A parent complains about gender representation in your materials.
questions.bestResponse: Review materials, consult stakeholders, update content if needed

questions.prompt: Your school bans a commonly used AI tool. You disagree. What now?
questions.bestResponse: Raise concerns professionally and suggest alternatives

questions.prompt: A student challenges your lesson on climate change as 'biased'.
questions.bestResponse: Facilitate respectful dialogue, acknowledge perspectives

questions.prompt: You're asked to lie to cover a scheduling error. What do you do?
questions.bestResponse: Refuse and explain ethical stance

questions.prompt: A student refuses to participate in group work due to anxiety.
questions.bestResponse: Offer alternative participation method and consult counselor

questions.prompt: You're offered a free EdTech product to trial in class — with no vetting.
questions.bestResponse: Decline until privacy and safety checks are complete

questions.prompt: You're asked to teach faster and skip key concepts.
questions.bestResponse: Explain risks of skipping and propose compromise

questions.prompt: Your supervisor insists on traditional rote methods you disagree with.
questions.bestResponse: Offer evidence-based alternatives respectfully
